data.title: Most Points in a Premier League Season
data.text:
Only one team in English top-flight history have managed to reach 100 points, but how close have other teams come? We look back at the most points won by clubs in a Premier League season.

Manchester City won the 2023-24 Premier League season to become the first club in the history of English football to win the top flight four years in a row. Just about seeing off Arsenal, City got over the line on the last day of the season and finished with 91 points.

Their historic achievement means there’s likely to be many clamouring to call them the greatest English side ever, though they’ve claimed even more points over a single season beforehand.

Here, we look at the teams to win the most points in an individual Premier League season, starting with the only side to accumulate 100 in a top-flight campaign in England…

100 points

Manchester City in 2017-18

Manchester City’s points return in 2017-18 set a new record. They only hit the century thanks to a stoppage-time goal from Gabriel Jesus away at Southampton on the final day of the season, but that 1-0 victory got them to a landmark no other team has ever reached in the top tier.

Their 32 wins set a new English top-flight record for a single season, but they replicated this feat only a year later when winning the title again in 2018-19, albeit with two points fewer (98). Sixteen of these wins came away from home – that was another Premier League record and equalled the all-time English top-flight record set in 1960-61 by Tottenham. However, based on three points for a win, City edged Spurs out on points with 50 in 2017-18 (W16 D2 L1) compared to Spurs’ haul of 49 (W16 D1 L4).

Eighteen of City’s 32 wins came in a consecutive run between 26 August and 27 December, setting another Premier League record (which has since been equalled by Liverpool), while their overall goal difference of +79 is still the best seen in the competition across one season.

The 2017-18 season also saw City score 106 goals in the Premier League, the most by a side in a single campaign since the competition began in 1992. The previous top-flight team to net more in an English league season were Spurs in 1962-63 (111), but they were still some distance off Aston Villa’s phenomenal 128 goals across 42 games in 1930-31, a campaign that still only saw them finish second behind Arsenal, who scored 127 times themselves.

All these records helped City smash yet another one: winning the Premier League title by a huge 19 points over second-placed Manchester United.

With Pep Guardiola’s first Premier League title as a manager, he added to his already packed honours list. This was a seventh top-flight league title after winning La Liga on three occasions with Barcelona as a coach and another three Bundesliga titles with Bayern Munich in Germany.

99 points

Liverpool in 2019-20

Liverpool won their first Premier League title ever and their first in the top-flight since 1989-90 with this outstanding campaign. The 2019-20 season was the strangest of all, with the COVID-19 pandemic forcing the season to an abrupt halt in March before returning in June without fans in stadiums – this didn’t stop the Reds from lifting the trophy, though.

When the season stopped on 9 March, Liverpool were 25 points clear of Manchester City at the top of the table on 82 points from 29 games. At a ratio of 2.83 points per game, Jürgen Klopp’s team were on course to break the 100-point barrier, but the enforced break affected this and Liverpool “only” managed 17 points in their remaining nine matches (1.89 per game).

Liverpool equalled the all-time English top-flight winning run of 18 games (set by Manchester City in 2017-18) in the 2019-20 campaign, with this run coming between October and February. It helped them seal the title after playing just 31 matches, following Man City’s defeat to Chelsea on 25 June, making it the earliest English title win in top-flight history.

This was Klopp’s hat-trick of top-flight league titles, after previously winning the German Bundesliga with Borussia Dortmund in 2010-11 and 2011-12.

98 points

Manchester City in 2018-19

Manchester City retained the Premier League title in 2018-19, something they’d failed to do following their first two successes in 2011-12 and 2013-14. Despite winning an outstanding 98 points, they still fell two points short of their Premier League record from 2017-18.

After suffering a shock 2-1 away defeat to Newcastle United on 29 January, City regained their focus to blow their challengers away – including Liverpool, who finished only one point below them. Guardiola’s side won their last 14 league matches, while also lifting the League Cup and FA Cup in this period. As they also won the Community Shield at the start of the campaign, City became the first side to ever hold all four of England’s primary football trophies.

City went into the final day of the season needing to defeat Brighton & Hove Albion away to make sure of back-to-back Premier League titles, and they did so in style. They suffered a minor scare, with Brighton’s Glenn Murray opening the scoring after 27 minutes, but the lead only lasted 83 seconds before Sergio Agüero equalised. Further goals from Aymeric Laporte, Riyad Mahrez and İlkay Gündoğan sealed the title.

This was the first time a side had retained the Premier League title since Manchester United did so in 2008-09, and something that City did so again in 2021-22, 2022-23 and 2023-24.

With 32 wins, they replicated their own English top-flight record from only a season before – but 2018-19 saw them lose two more games (four) than they did in 2017-18 (two). City also set seasonal records for most minutes leading (2,088) and fewest minutes trailing (132) in a single Premier League season.

97 points

Liverpool in 2018-19

Liverpool pushed Manchester City all the way in 2018-19, but their fantastic tally of 97 fell just short of helping them secure their first Premier League title. In fact, their total was the most by any team not to win an English top-flight title – no team has ever won 90+ points and 30+ games in a single season without lifting the English top-flight trophy before or since 2018-19.

The Reds had the best defensive record, but their mean backline wasn’t enough to win them the title. They kept the most clean sheets (21) while conceding 22 goals – only Arsenal in 1998-99 (17) have conceded fewer goals and failed to win the Premier League title in a season.

Liverpool also scored 89 goals, six fewer than Man City (95), but they did end the season with two of the three Premier League Golden Boot winners. Both Mohamed Salah and Sadio Mané scored 22 times, finishing level best with Arsenal’s Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang.

95 points

Chelsea in 2004-05

José Mourinho was introduced to the Premier League in 2004-05 as he took charge of Chelsea following back-to-back league titles in Portugal with FC Porto. Even more impressive was his UEFA Champions League success with the Portuguese side only a week before his move to London.

Mourinho’s first season at Chelsea saw an awesome defensive exhibition, with 25 clean sheets and only 15 goals conceded setting Premier League records by a team in a single season. The only other team to concede as few as 15 goals in an English top-flight season were Preston North End in 1888-89, but they only played 22 matches that season.

Chelsea’s title win was their first in 50 years, while their 95-point tally was the most in an English top-flight season until Man City’s astonishing 2017-18 campaign.

Chelsea’s average starting XI age in this season was just 25 years and 250 days old – it remains the youngest to win a Premier League title. Mourinho had brought in players that would go on to become longer-term heroes, such as Didier Drogba, Paulo Ferreira, Ricardo Carvalho, Arjen Robben and Petr Čech. The latter conceded only 13 goals in his 35 league appearances in this title-winning campaign, while his personal tally of 24 clean sheets is still the most by a goalkeeper in a single Premier League season.

This season can also be remembered for possibly the best relegation battle the Premier League has seen – no side was relegated until the final day, with Southampton, Norwich City and Crystal Palace eventually dropping to the Championship.

93 points

Chelsea in 2016-17, Manchester City in 2021-22

The closest Chelsea have got to their club-record tally of 95 points in 2004-05 was in Antonio Conte’s first campaign as manager in 2016-17. They won the title with 93 points, which was seven ahead of Tottenham, whom he also went on to manage.

Spurs could count themselves unlucky in 2016-17, with the north London club having both the best record for goals scored (86) and goals conceded (26), while losing fewer matches (four) than Chelsea (five).

Leicester City came into 2016-17 as the reigning Champions following their shock success a season before, but the Foxes finished 12th and set the record for the worst title defence in the Premier League era.

From November 20 to the end of the season, Chelsea spent all but one of the 183 days of the season in first place – only being knocked off top for one day by Arsenal. Before that point, Chelsea had only ended two of the previous 99 days top of the league, timing their form to perfection.

Manchester City also amassed 93 points in 2021-22, when they won their eighth top-flight English league title and their sixth in the Premier League era.

They did it the hard way eventually, with their 3-2 victory against Aston Villa on the final day only coming after being two goals behind with just 15 minutes left to play. With Liverpool winning against Wolves at Anfield, City knew nothing less than a victory would seal the title – luckily for them, they came from two goals down to win a league game for the first time since February 2005 against Norwich at Carrow Road. Guardiola’s men finished with a +73 goal difference, which has only been bettered once in the Premier League era – by City themselves in 2017-18 (+79).

Another feature of this title victory was City’s ability to hold onto a lead. They equalled the Premier League record for fewest points dropped from winning positions in a season (two), doing this across 30 matches – the same record as Chelsea in 2004-05 during Mourinho’s first campaign in charge of the Blues.

92 points

Manchester United in 1993-94, Liverpool in 2021-22

After their title win in the inaugural Premier League season, Manchester United sealed a second in succession in 1993-94, picking up eight more points than the previous campaign in the process. Of the three Premier League seasons to contain 42 games, this was the highest points tally (84).

The 1993-94 season was 268 days long in total, and Manchester United were top of the league at the end of 262 of those – only Aston Villa (three), Everton (one), Liverpool (one) and Ipswich Town (one) led the table for a night other than United, with all six of those nights coming in the first nine days of the campaign.

United scored fewer goals (80) than third-placed Newcastle United (82), while they conceded more (38) than runners-up Blackburn Rovers (36).

Sir Alex Ferguson’s side had their fantastic start to the season to thank for their success. They dropped only four points in their first 15 matches (W13 D1 L1), but from November 24 onwards they were to win 52 points from 27 games – less than Blackburn (55) and level with Newcastle (52). Only a season later, United lost the title to Blackburn.

And oh dear, it’s another Liverpool entry in a season when they didn’t win the title.

Klopp’s men finished the 2021-22 season on 92 points, the second-highest total by a side that didn’t go on to win the title in English top-flight history, behind only their own 97 in 2018-19. And once again it was Manchester City who pipped them to it.

Klopp must be cursing that he had to exist in the same timeline as Guardiola’s City team. If it weren’t for the Catalan coach, Liverpool would almost certainly have three Premier League titles to their name by now, and all the talk about a dynasty would be red-themed, rather than sky blue.

Liverpool lost just two games across the whole season, one fewer than title-winners Manchester City, and their +68 goal difference was their highest in a single Premier League season.

91 points

Manchester United in 1999-00, Chelsea in 2005-06, Manchester City in 2023-24

Manchester United came off the back of a historic treble to secure their highest points-per-game tally in a single Premier League campaign (2.39) during the 1999-00 season. Their title success going into the new century wasn’t built on a solid defence though, with United conceding 45 goals in total, the most of any Premier League champion.

United were excellent at Old Trafford in 1999-00, winning 15 and drawing four of their 19 games at home and finished their title-winning season with 11 wins on the bounce.

The 18-point gap between United and Arsenal in second is the second-biggest seen in an English top-flight season, with only Man City’s 19-point gap over United themselves in 2017-18 being greater.

Another team to hit 91 points in a season were Chelsea in 2005-06, following up their title win in Mourinho’s debut season with a second in succession.

Chelsea won their first nine games to the season, which remains a Premier League record. They were also the first team in Premier League history to beat every other team in a single season, a feat that has since been replicated by Man Utd (2010-11, 2017-18), Man City (2017-18, 2018-19) and Liverpool (2019-20).

Chelsea first spent a night on top of the 2005-06 Premier League table on August 24 – 12 days into the season. They didn’t spend a night off it from this point on.

Manchester City’s class of 2023-24 also accumulated 91 points. That was enough to pip Arsenal to the title by two points, meaning the Gunners’ total is the third most by a team not to win the Premier League title.

City didn’t always look certainties for the the 2023-24 crown, with Arsenal arguably the best team over the course of the campaign. But Guardiola’s men ended the season with eight league wins on the bounce and on a 23-match unbeaten run in the competition.

That took them to a fourth successive top-flight league title, something never achieved by any club beforehand in English football, and moved Pep Guardiola on to six crowns behind only Alex Ferguson.

90 points

Arsenal in 2003-04, Manchester United in 2008-09

Arsenal’s Invincibles reigned supreme in 2003-04, as the Premier League winners ended the season without losing a single game. This is still the only case of a side doing this in an English top-flight season with at least 38 games, with only Preston North End in 1888-89 managing an unbeaten campaign from a 22-game season.

The Gunners won the league by 11 points ahead of Manchester United, but Arsène Wenger’s side did draw 12 of their 38 matches – only one Premier League champion has ever drawn more: Man Utd in 1998-99 (13).

Manchester United also posted a 90-point tally in 2008-09 on the way to their 18th English top-flight title. This was the season when the Red Devils finally caught up with Liverpool’s tally of league crowns in the top division.

During their title-winning season, United kept 24 clean sheets with 14 of these coming in successive appearances for goalkeeper Edwin van der Sar. His spell of 21 hours and 50 minutes without conceding a single goal is an all-time Premier League record.
